data: The solar neutrino capture rate measured by the Russian-American Gallium Experiment (SAGE) on metallic gallium during the period January 1990 through December 1997 is 67.2− 7.0− 3.0+ 7.2+ 3.5 SNU, where the uncertainties are statistical and systematic, respectively. This represents only about half of the predicted standard solar model rate of 129 SNU. All the experimental procedures, including extraction of germanium from gallium, counting of 71 Ge, and data analysis, are discussed in detail.
Measurement of the solar neutrino capture rate with gallium metal

The solar neutrino capture rate measured by the Russian-American Gallium Experiment (SAGE) on metallic gallium during the period January 1990 through December 1997 is 67.2− 7.0− 3.0+ 7.2+ 3.5 SNU, where the uncertainties are statistical and systematic, respectively. This represents only about half of the predicted standard solar model rate of 129 SNU. All the experimental procedures, including extraction of germanium from gallium, counting of 71 Ge, and data analysis, are discussed in detail.
Measurement of the solar neutrino capture rate with gallium metal

The solar neutrino capture rate measured by the Russian-American Gallium Experiment (SAGE) on metallic gallium during the period January 1990 through December 1997 is 67.2− 7.0− 3.0+ 7.2+ 3.5 SNU, where the uncertainties are statistical and systematic, respectively. This represents only about half of the predicted standard solar model rate of 129 SNU. All the experimental procedures, including extraction of germanium from gallium, counting of 71 Ge, and data analysis, are discussed in detail.
Measurement of the solar neutrino capture rate with gallium metal

JN Abdurashitov and VN Gavrin and SV Girin and VV Gorbachev and TV Ibragimova and AV Kalikhov and NG Khairnasov and TV Knodel and IN Mirmov and AA Shikhin and EP Veretenkin and VM Vermul and VE Yants and GT Zatsepin and TJ Bowles and WA Teasdale and DL Wark and ML Cherry and JS Nico and BT Cleveland and R Davis Jr and K Lande and PS Wildenhain and SR Elliott and JF Wilkerson and SAGE Collaboration

https://journals.aps.org/prc/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevC.60.055801

The Russian-American experiment SAGE began to measure the solar neutrino capture rate with a target of gallium metal in December 1989. Measurements have continued with only a few brief interruptions since that time. In this article we present the experimental improvements in SAGE since its last published data summary in December 2001. Assuming the solar neutrino production rate was constant during the period of data collection, combined analysis of 168 extractions through December 2007 gives a capture rate of solar neutrinos with energy more than 233 keV of 65. 4− 3. 0+ 3. 1 (stat)− 2. 8+ 2. 6 (syst) SNU. The weighted average of the results of all three Ga solar neutrino experiments, SAGE, Gallex, and GNO, is now 66. 1±3. 1 SNU, where statistical and systematic uncertainties have been combined in quadrature. During the recent period of data collection a new test of SAGE was made with a reactor …
Measurement of the solar neutrino capture rate with gallium metal. III. Results for the 2002–2007 data-taking period

JN Abdurashitov and VN Gavrin and VV Gorbachev and PP Gurkina and TV Ibragimova and AV Kalikhov and NG Khairnasov and TV Knodel and IN Mirmov and AA Shikhin and EP Veretenkin and VE Yants and GT Zatsepin and TJ Bowles and SR Elliott and WA Teasdale and JS Nico and BT Cleveland and JF Wilkerson and SAGE Collaboration

https://journals.aps.org/prc/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevC.80.015807

Fifteen measurements of the solar neutrino flux have been made in a radiochemical 71Ga-71Ge experiment employing initially 30 t and later 57 t of liquid metallic gallium at the Baksan Neutrino Observatory between January 1990 and May 1992. This provides an integral measurement of the flux of solar neutrinos and in particular is sensitive to the dominant, low-energy p-p solar neutrinos. SAGE observed the capture rate to be 73−16+18 (stat.)−7+5 (syst.) SNU. This represents only 56%−60% of the capture rate predicted by different Standard Solar Models.
Results from SAGE (The Russian-American gallium solar neutrino experiment)

JN Abdurashitov and EL Faizov and VN Gavrin and AO Gusev and AV Kalikhov and TV Knodel and II Knyshenko and VN Kornoukhov and IN Mirmov and AM Pshukov and AM Shalagin and AA Shikhin and PV Timofeyev and EP Veretenkin and VM Vermul and GT Zatsepin and TJ Bowles and JS Nico and WA Teasdale and DL Wark and JF Wilkerson and BT Cleveland and T Daily and R Davis Jr and K Lande and CK Lee and PW Wildenhain and SR Elliott and ML Cherry and RT Kouzes
uFxoO_IAAAAJ:d1gkVwhDpl0C
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0370269394904545

The solar neutrino capture rate measured by SAGE is well below that predicted by solar models. To check the overall experimental efficiency, we exposed 13 tonnes of Ga metal to a reactor-produced 517 kCi source of 51 Cr. The ratio of the measured production rate to that predicted from the source activity is 0.95±0.11 (stat)+ 0.05/− 0.08 (syst). This agreement verifies that the experimental efficiency is measured correctly, establishes that there are no unknown systematic errors at the 10% level, and provides considerable evidence for the reliability of the solar neutrino measurement.
The Russian-American gallium experiment (SAGE) Cr neutrino source measurement

JN Abdurashitov and VN Gavrin and SV Girin and VV Gorbachev and TV Ibragimova and AV Kalikhov and NG Khairnasov and TV Knodel and VN Kornoukhov and IN Mirmov and AA Shikhin and EP Veretenkin and VM Vermul and VE Yants and GT Zatsepin and TJ Bowles and JS Nico and WA Teasdale and DL Wark and ML Cherry and VN Karaulov and VL Levitin and VI Maev and PI Nazarenko and VS Shkol'Nik and NV Skorikov and BT Cleveland and T Daily and R Davis Jr and K Lande and CK Lee and PW Wildenhain and Yu S Khomyakov and AV Zvonarev and SR Elliott and JF Wilkerson

https://journals.aps.org/prl/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevLett.77.4708
This white paper addresses the hypothesis of light sterile neutrinos based on recent anomalies observed in neutrino experiments and the latest astrophysical data.
Light sterile neutrinos: a white paper

Kevork N Abazajian and MA Acero and SK Agarwalla and AA Aguilar-Arevalo and CH Albright and S Antusch and CA Arguelles and AB Balantekin and G Barenboim and V Barger and P Bernardini and F Bezrukov and OE Bjaelde and SA Bogacz and NS Bowden and A Boyarsky and A Bravar and D Bravo Berguno and SJ Brice and AD Bross and B Caccianiga and F Cavanna and EJ Chun and BT Cleveland and AP Collin and P Coloma and JM Conrad and M Cribier and AS Cucoanes and JC d'Olivo and S Das and A De Gouvea and AV Derbin and R Dharmapalan and JS Diaz and XJ Ding and Z Djurcic and A Donini and D Duchesneau and H Ejiri and SR Elliott and DJ Ernst and A Esmaili and JJ Evans and E Fernandez-Martinez and E Figueroa-Feliciano and BT Fleming and JA Formaggio and D Franco and J Gaffiot and R Gandhi and Y Gao and GT Garvey and VN Gavrin and P Ghoshal and D Gibin and C Giunti and SN Gninenko and VV Gorbachev and DS Gorbunov and R Guenette and A Guglielmi and F Halzen and J Hamann and S Hannestad and W Haxton and KM Heeger and R Henning and P Hernandez and Patrick Huber and W Huelsnitz and A Ianni and TV Ibragimova and Y Karadzhov and G Karagiorgi and G Keefer and YD Kim and Joachim Kopp and VN Kornoukhov and A Kusenko and P Kyberd and P Langacker and Th Lasserre and M Laveder and A Letourneau and D Lhuillier and YF Li and Manfred Lindner and JM Link and BL Littlejohn and P Lombardi and K Long and J Lopez-Pavon and WC Louis and L Ludhova and JD Lykken and PAN Machado and M Maltoni and WA Mann and D Marfatia
uFxoO_IAAAAJ:TQgYirikUcIC
https://arxiv.org/abs/1204.5379

We present measurements of the solar neutrino capture rate on metallic gallium in the Soviet-American gallium experiment (SAGE) over a period of slightly more than half the 22-year solar cycle. A combined analysis of 92 runs over the twelve-year period from January 1990 until December 2001 yields a capture rate of 70.8                   −5.2 +5.3                  (stat)                   −3.2 +3.7                  (sys) SNU for solar neutrinos with energies above 0.233 MeV. This value is slightly more than half the rate predicted by the standard solar model, 130 SNU. We present the results of new runs since April 1998 and analyze all runs combined by years, months, and bimonthly periods beginning in 1990. A simple analysis of the SAGE results together with the results of other solar neutrino experiments gives an estimate of (4.6±1.2)× 1010 neutrinos cm−2 s−1 for the flux of the electron pp neutrinos that reach …
Solar neutrino flux measurements by the Soviet-American gallium experiment (SAGE) for half the 22-year solar cycle
